<math><msqrt><mrow><mo>-</mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>9</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>x</mi></mrow></msqrt></math>
 is continuous 
<math><mrow><mo>⇔</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>x</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>≤</mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>0</mn></mrow></math>
, while 
<math><mrow><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>
 is continuous everywhere in 
<math><mi>ℝ</mi></math>
.

object.question:
Determine where 
<math><mrow><mrow><mi>F</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msqrt><mrow><mn>9</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></msqrt><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mi>tan</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mrow><mn>5</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><msqrt><mi>x</mi></msqrt></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>
 is continuous.
object.hint:

 .

.

object.hint:

<math><mi>f</mi></math>
 is discontinuous at 
<math><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>13</mn></mrow></mrow></math>
.
object.explanation:
A function 
<math><mrow><mi>g</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>
 has a removable discontinuity at a point 
<math><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow></math>
 
<math><mo>⇔</mo></math>
 
<math><mrow><munder><mi>lim</mi><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow></munder><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mi>g</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>
 exists, but it is not equal to 
<math><mrow><mi>g</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>
. Similarly, 
<math><mrow><mi>g</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>
 has a jump discontinuity at a point 
<math><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>d</mi></mrow></math>

<math><mo>⇔</mo></math>
 
<math><mrow><munder><mi>lim</mi><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><msup><mi>c</mi><mtext>+</mtext></msup></mrow></munder><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mi>g</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mtext> </mtext><mo>≠</mo><mtext> </mtext><munder><mi>lim</mi><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><msup><mi>c</mi><mtext>-</mtext></msup></mrow></munder><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mi>g</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>
.

.

object.question:
Consider the function f defined by

f⁡(x)={15-14⁢x225 - 14⁢ x ,if⁢ x ≠ 22514 ,0 ,if⁢ x = 22514 .

object.explanation:
A function 
<math><mrow><mi>g</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>
 has a removable discontinuity at a point 
<math><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow></math>
 
<math><mo>⇔</mo></math>
 
<math><mrow><munder><mi>lim</mi><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow></munder><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mi>g</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>
 exists, but it is not equal to

. Similarly,

object.question:
If 
<math><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mtext> </mtext><mo>-</mo><mtext> </mtext><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mtext> </mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>4</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></math>
, then:

options.statement:
there exists a number 
<math><mi>c</mi></math>
 such that 
<math><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></math>
.

there exists a number 
<math><mi>c</mi></math>
 in 
<math><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mn>0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mo>,</mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow></math>
 such that 
<math><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></math>
.

there exists a number 
<math><mi>c</mi></math>
 in 
<math><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mtext> </mtext><mo>,</mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>1.5</mn></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow></math>
 such that 
<math><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>13</mn></mrow></math>
.

there exists no number 
<math><mi>c</mi></math>
 such that 
<math><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></math>
.

object.hint:
<math><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="bold"><mrow><mi>Intermediate</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>Value</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>Theorem</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>:</mo></mrow></mstyle></mrow></math>
  Suppose that 
<math><mi>g</mi></math>
 is continuous on the closed interval 
<math><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mi>a</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>,</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>b</mi></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow></math>
 and let 
<math><mi>N</mi></math>
 be any number between 
<math><mrow><mi>g</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>
 and 
<math><mrow><mi>g</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>
, where 
<math><mrow><mrow><mi>g</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mtext> </mtext><mo>≠</mo><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mi>g</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>
. Then there exists a number 
<math><mi>c</mi></math>
 in 
<math><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>a</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>,</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>b</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>
 such that 
<math><mrow><mrow><mi>g</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>N</mi></mrow></math>
.
object.explanation:
Since 
<math><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>
 is a polynomial function, it is continuous everywhere in 
<math><mi>ℝ</mi></math>
. Hence, it is continuous in 
<math><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mtext> </mtext><mo>,</mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>2</mn></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow></math>
. Now apply the Intermediate Value Theorem.

object.question:
Compute the left hand derivative f_′(x) and the right hand derivative f+′(x) of the function f defined by

f⁡(x)={0 ,if⁢ x ≤ 0 ,10 - x ,if⁢ 0 < x < 9 , and110 - x ,if⁢ x ≥ 9

at x=9 .
object.hint:
The left hand and the right hand derivatives of a function 
<math><mi>f</mi></math>
 at 
<math><mi>c</mi></math>
 are defined by 
<math><mrow><mrow><msup><msub><mi>f</mi><mtext>_</mtext></msub><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><munder><mi>lim</mi><mrow><mi>h</mi><mo>→</mo><msup><mn>0</mn><mtext>-</mtext></msup></mrow></munder><mtext> </mtext><mfrac><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>c</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>h</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mtext> </mtext><mo>-</mo><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mi>h</mi></mfrac></mrow></mrow></math>
 and 
<math><mrow><mrow><msup><msub><mi>f</mi><mtext>+</mtext></msub><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><munder><mi>lim</mi><mrow><mi>h</mi><mo>→</mo><msup><mn>0</mn><mtext>+</mtext></msup></mrow></munder><mtext> </mtext><mfrac><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>c</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>h</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mtext> </mtext><mo>-</mo><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mi>h</mi></mfrac></mrow></mrow></math>
.
object.explanation:
Note that 
<math><mrow><mrow><msup><msub><mi>f</mi><mtext>_</mtext></msub><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>(</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><munder><mi>lim</mi><mrow><mi>h</mi><mo>→</mo><msup><mn>0</mn><mtext>-</mtext></msup></mrow></munder><mtext> </mtext><mfrac><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mn>9</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mn>9</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>h</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>h</mi></mfrac></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mrow></math>
. Similarly, evaluate the right hand derivative at 
<math><mn>9</mn></math>
.

object.question:
Consider the function

f⁡(x)=35 - 59⁢ x29 + 9⁢ x .

Find the domain of f′(x) .
object.hint:
The derivative of a function f is defined as

f′(x)=limh→0 f⁡(x + h) - f⁡(x)h ,

if the limit exists.
object.explanation:
To find 
<math><mrow><msup><mi>f</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>
,  evaluate  
<math><mrow><munder><mi>lim</mi><mrow><mi>h</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></munder><mtext> </mtext><mfrac><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>35</mn><mtext> </mtext><mo>-</mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>59</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>h</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>29</mn><mtext> </mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>9</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>h</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac><mtext> </mtext><mo>-</mo><mtext> </mtext><mfrac><mrow><mn>35</mn><mtext> </mtext><mo>-</mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>59</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>29</mn><mtext> </mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>9</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mi>h</mi></mfrac></mrow></math>
.

object.question:
Consider the function 
<math><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>x</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>-</mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>11</mn></mrow></msqrt></mrow></math>
. Find the domain of 
<math><mrow><msup><mi>f</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>
.
object.hint:
The derivative of a function f , denoted by f′(x) is defined as

f′(x)=limh→0 f⁡(x + h) - f⁡(x)h ,

if the limit exists.
object.explanation:
To compute 
<math><mrow><msup><mi>f</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>
,  evaluate 
<math><mrow><munder><mi>lim</mi><mrow><mi>h</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></munder><mtext> </mtext><mfrac><mrow><msqrt><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>h</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mtext> </mtext><mo>-</mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>11</mn></mrow></msqrt><mtext> </mtext><mo>-</mo><mtext> </mtext><msqrt><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>x</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>-</mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>11</mn></mrow></msqrt></mrow><mi>h</mi></mfrac></mrow></math>
 by rationalizing the numerator.

object.question:
Let 
<math><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>{</mo><mrow><mtable columnalign="left" ><mtr><mtd><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>x</mi></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow><mtext> </mtext><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mi>if</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>x</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>≠</mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mn>0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mi>if</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>x</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>=</mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mo>.</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>
 \[\]Then, which of the following statements is true?
object.hint:
The derivative of a function f is defined as

f′(x)=limh→0 f⁡(x + h) - f⁡(x)h ,

if the limit exists.
object.explanation:
Note that 
<math><mrow><mrow><msup><mi>f</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><munder><mi>lim</mi><mrow><mi>h</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></munder><mtext> </mtext><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>h</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>h</mi></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow><mtext> </mtext><mo>-</mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>0</mn></mrow><mi>h</mi></mfrac></mrow></mrow></math>
. Now apply the Squeeze Theorem to evaluate the limit.

object.question:
Consider the limit

limt→ 1.5 t4 + t - 6.6t-1.5 .

If this represents the derivative of some function f at some number c , then find f and c .
object.hint:
The derivative of a function f at a number c is defined as

f′(c)=limx→c f⁡(x) - f⁡(c)x - c ,

if the limit exists.
object.explanation:
Since
<math><mrow><mrow><munder><mi>lim</mi><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>1.5</mn></mrow></munder><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><msup><mi>t</mi><mn>4</mn></msup><mtext> </mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>t</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>-</mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>6.6</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><munder><mi>lim</mi><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>1.5</mn></mrow></munder><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>-</mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>1.5</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></math>
, apply the  L'Hospital's rule.

If this represents the derivative of some function f at some number c , then find f and c .
object.hint:
The derivative of a function f at a number c is defined as

f′(c)=limx→c f⁡(x) - f⁡(c)x - c ,

if the limit exists.
object.explanation:
Since
<math><mrow><mrow><munder><mi>lim</mi><mfrac><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>π</mi></mrow><mn>6</mn></mfrac></munder><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>tan</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mrow><mn>7</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mtext> </mtext><mo>-</mo><mtext> </mtext><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msqrt><mn>3</mn></msqrt></mfrac></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><munder><mi>lim</mi><mfrac><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>π</mi></mrow><mn>6</mn></mfrac></munder><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>-</mo><mtext> </mtext><mfrac><mi>π</mi><mn>6</mn></mfrac></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></math>
, apply the  L'Hospital's rule.

object.question:
Consider the limit

limx→⁢ π3 tan⁡(x) - 3x - π3 .

If this represents the derivative of some function f at some number c , then find f and c .
object.hint:
The derivative of a function f at a number c is defined as

f′(c)=limx→c f⁡(x) - f⁡(c)x - c ,

if the limit exists.
object.explanation:
Since
<math><mrow><mrow><munder><mi>lim</mi><mfrac><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>π</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn></mfrac></munder><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>tan</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mtext> </mtext><mo>-</mo><mtext> </mtext><msqrt><mn>3</mn></msqrt></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><munder><mi>lim</mi><mfrac><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>π</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn></mfrac></munder><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>-</mo><mtext> </mtext><mfrac><mi>π</mi><mn>3</mn></mfrac></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></math>
, apply the  L'Hospital's rule.

Since
<math><mrow><munder><mi>lim</mi><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></munder><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><msup><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi></msup><mtext> </mtext><mo>-</mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>25</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>
 and

 are zero, apply the  L'Hospital's rule.

object.question:
Consider the limit

limh→0 243 + h5 - 3h .

If this represents the derivative of some function f at some number c , then find f and c .
object.hint:
The derivative of a function f at a number c is defined as

f′(c)=limh→0 f⁡(c+h) - f⁡(c)h ,

if the limit exists.
object.explanation:
Note that, by the Binomial Theorem,  \[(p +h)^{q} = \displaystyle \sum_{k =0}^{\infty} {q \choose k} p^{q - k} h^{k} , \] where 
<math><mi>k</mi></math>
 is a non negative  integer and 
<math><mi>q</mi></math>
 is a non integral power. Now, check whether the above limit exists or not.

object.explanation:
Note that, by the Binomial theorem,  \[(p +h)^{q} = \displaystyle \sum_{k =0}^{\infty} {q \choose k} p^{q - k} h^{k} , \] where

 is a non negative  integer and 
<math><mi>q</mi></math>

object.question:
A Tibetan monk leaves the monastery at 
<math><mn>5</mn></math>
 a.m and takes his usual path to the top of the mountain, arriving at 
<math><mn>5</mn></math>
 p.m. The following morning, he starts at 
<math><mn>5</mn></math>
 a.m at the top and takes the same path back, arriving at the monastery at 
<math><mn>5</mn></math>
 p.m. Is there a point on the path that the monk will cross at exactly the same time of day on both days?

options.statement:
Yes, there is a time between   the
<math><msup><mn>0</mn><mi>th</mi></msup></math>
    and   the
<math><msup><mn>6</mn><mi>th</mi></msup></math>
   hour when the two paths meet.

Yes, there is a time  between   the
<math><msup><mn>6</mn><mi>th</mi></msup></math>
   and   the
<math><msup><mn>12</mn><mi>th</mi></msup></math>
   hour when the two paths meet.

Yes, there is a  time between  the
<math><msup><mn>0</mn><mi>th</mi></msup></math>
  and    the
<math><msup><mn>12</mn><mi>th</mi></msup></math>
   hour when the two paths meet.
The paths to and from the mountain will never meet at the same time.

object.hint:
Define 
<math><mrow><mi>u</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>
 to be the monk's distance from the monastery, as a function of time on the first day, and define 
<math><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>
 to be the from the monastery, as a function of time on the second day. Let 
<math><mi>D</mi></math>
 be the distance from the monastery to the top of the mountain. Note that both 
<math><mi>d</mi></math>
 and 
<math><mi>D</mi></math>
 are continuous functions.  Now, consider the function 
<math><mrow><mi>u</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>d</mi></mrow></math>
.
object.explanation:
Note that 
<math><mrow><mrow><mi>u</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></math>
, 
<math><mrow><mrow><mi>u</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>D</mi></mrow></math>
, 
<math><mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>D</mi></mrow></math>
 and 
<math><mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></math>
. Now,  apply the Intermediate Value Theorem for the time interval 
<math><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mn>0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mo>,</mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>12</mn></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow></math>
.

object.question:
Determine where the function g defined by

g⁡(x)={0 ,if⁢ x⁢ is⁢ rational , andx ,if⁢ x⁢ is⁢ irrational

continuous.
object.hint:
Note that 
<math><mrow><mo>-</mo><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mo>|</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>|</mo></mrow><mtext> </mtext><mo>≤</mo><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mi>g</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mtext> </mtext><mo>≤</mo><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mo>|</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>|</mo></mrow></mrow></math>
. Hence apply Squeeze Theorem as 
<math><mrow><mi>x</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>→</mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>0</mn></mrow></math>
.
object.explanation:
For a ≠ 0 , consider the function

f⁡(x)={0 ,if⁢ x⁢ is⁢ rational , anda ,if⁢ x⁢ is⁢ irrational .

Suppose that limx→0 f⁢ (x)=L . Then, given ϵ > 0 , there exists δ > 0 such that |x| < δ ⇒ |f⁡(x)| < ϵ . Now choose x0 ∈ (x - δ , x + δ) , which is irrational. Then f⁡(x0)=a > ϵ , when ϵ is sufficiently small, which contradicts our assumption. Using a similar argument, determine whether the limit exists at points other than 0 .

object.question:
For what values of x is the function defined by

f⁡(x)={0 ,if⁢x⁢is⁢rational,and23 ,if⁢ x⁢ is⁢ irrational

continuous ?
object.hint:
If 
<math><mrow><mrow><munder><mi>lim</mi><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow></munder><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>L</mi></mrow></math>
, then,  given 
<math><mrow><mi>ϵ</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>></mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>0</mn></mrow></math>
, there exists 
<math><mrow><mi>δ</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>></mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>0</mn></mrow></math>
 such that 
<math><mrow><mrow><mo>|</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow><mo>|</mo></mrow><mtext> </mtext><mo><</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>δ</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>⇒</mo><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mo>|</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>L</mi></mrow><mo>|</mo></mrow><mtext> </mtext><mo><</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>ϵ</mi></mrow></math>
.
object.explanation:
Suppose that 
<math><mrow><mrow><munder><mi>lim</mi><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></munder><mtext> </mtext><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>L</mi></mrow></math>
.  Then, given 
<math><mrow><mi>ϵ</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>></mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>0</mn></mrow></math>
, there exists 
<math><mrow><mi>δ</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>></mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>0</mn></mrow></math>
 such that 
<math><mrow><mrow><mo>|</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>|</mo></mrow><mtext> </mtext><mo><</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>δ</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>⇒</mo><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mo>|</mo><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>|</mo></mrow><mtext> </mtext><mo><</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>ϵ</mi></mrow></math>
. Now choose 
<math><mrow><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mtext> </mtext><mo>∈</mo><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>-</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>δ</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>,</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>x</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>δ</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>
, which is irrational. Then 
<math><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mn>23</mn><mtext> </mtext><mo>></mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>ϵ</mi></mrow></mrow></math>
, when 
<math><mi>ϵ</mi></math>
 is sufficiently small, which contradicts our assumption. Use a similar argument to determine whether the limit exists at other points.

object.hint: Intermediate Value Theorem: Suppose that g is continuous on the closed interval [a , b] and let N be any number between g⁡(a) and g⁡(b) , where g⁡(a) ≠ g⁡(b) . Then there exists a number c in (a , b) such that g⁡(c)=N .

<math><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mi>a</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>,</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>b</mi></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow></math>
 such that

 and 
<math><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>
  have opposite signs and apply the Intermediate Value Theorem.

. Then there exists a number

object.hint:
Consider the function 
<math><mrow><mrow><mi>g</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>{</mo><mrow><mtable columnalign="left" ><mtr><mtd><mrow><mo>-</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>x</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mi>if</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>x</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>≥</mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mo>,</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>and</mi></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mi>x</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mi>if</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>x</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo><</mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mo>.</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

object.question:
For a function 
<math><mrow><mi>f</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>:</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>ℝ</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>→</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>ℝ</mi></mrow></math>
,  consider the following statements: \[\]
(i) If 
<math><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>
 is even, then 
<math><mrow><msup><mi>f</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>
 is odd. \[\]
(ii) If 
<math><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>
 is odd, then 
<math><mrow><msup><mi>f</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>
 is odd.  \[\] Then
object.hint:
A function 
<math><mrow><mi>f</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>:</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>ℝ</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>→</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>ℝ</mi></mrow></math>
 is said to be \[\]
(i)
<math><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mi>even</mi></mstyle></mrow></math>
  if
<math><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mtext> </mtext><mo>,</mo><mtext> </mtext><mo>∀</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>x</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>∈</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>ℝ</mi></mrow></mrow></math>
, and \[\] (ii) 
<math><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mi>odd</mi></mstyle></mrow></math>
 if 
<math><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mtext> </mtext><mo>,</mo><mtext> </mtext><mo>∀</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>x</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>∈</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>ℝ</mi></mrow></mrow></math>
.
object.explanation:
Note that for an odd function 
<math><mi>f</mi></math>
, 
<math><mrow><mrow><msup><mi>f</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><munder><mi>lim</mi><mrow><mi>h</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></munder><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow><mtext>+</mtext></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>h</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mi>h</mi></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mrow><munder><mi>lim</mi><mrow><mi>h</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></munder><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mtext>-</mtext></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>h</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mi>h</mi></mfrac></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><munder><mi>lim</mi><mrow><mi>h</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></munder><mtext> </mtext><mfrac><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mtext>-</mtext></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>h</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mtext>-</mtext><mi>h</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msup><mi>f</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>
.

Let 
<math><mrow><mrow><mi>h</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mn>6</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mtext> </mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>7</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mi>g</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>
,

object.question:
Find the points on the curve 
<math><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>9</mn></msup><mtext> </mtext><mo>-</mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>6</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>7</mn></msup><mtext> </mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>666</mn></mrow></mrow></math>
, where the tangent line is horizontal.
object.hint: Horizontal tangents to the curve occur at those points where  the slope of the  tangent is zero.
object.explanation:
Find 
<math><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></math>
 and equate it to zero.

object.question:
At what points on the hyperbola 
<math><mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></math>
 is the tangent line parallel to the line 
<math><mrow><mrow><mn>12</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>x</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>8</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>y</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></math>
.
object.hint: Note that parallel lines have the same slope.
object.explanation:
Evaluate the slope of the tangent  ( i.e. 
<math><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></math>
 )  to the hyperbola 
<math><mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></math>
 at the point 
<math><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>
  and equate it to the slope of the line 
<math><mrow><mrow><mn>12</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>x</mi><mtext> </mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>8</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>y</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></math>
.

 at a point

.
object.hint:

<math><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></math>
 at 
<math><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></math>
.
object.explanation:
Note that the product of the slopes of the tangent and the normal  at any given point on the curve is 
<math><mrow><mo>-</mo><mtext> </mtext><mn>1</mn></mrow></math>
.

object.question:

whose graph has horizontal tangents at the points (-2,6) and (2,0) .
object.hint: Horizontal tangents to the curve occur at those points where the slope of the tangent is zero.

 at the points

 and 
<math><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>
  and equate it to zero.

object.question:
Let 
<math><mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>a</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></msup></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msub><mi>a</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mo>·</mo><mo>·</mo><mo>·</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msub><mi>a</mi><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>a</mi><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow></mrow></math>
. Then,
<math><mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>a</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>A</mi><mi>n</mi></msup></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msub><mi>a</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>A</mi><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mo>·</mo><mo>·</mo><mo>·</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msub><mi>a</mi><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>A</mi></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msub><mi>a</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>I</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>
, where A is a square matrix.  Suppose, 
<math><mrow><mi>D</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>[</mo><mtable><mtr><mtd><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></math>
 and 
<math><mrow><mrow><mi>q</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>3</mn></msup></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>11</mn></mrow></mrow></math>
. Then, Trace of 
<math><mrow><mi>q</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>D</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>
 is:
object.hint:
If 
<math><mrow><mi>P</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>[</mo><mtable><mtr><mtd><msub><mi>p</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><msub><mi>p</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><msub><mi>p</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><msub><mi>p</mi><mn>4</mn></msub></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><msub><mi>p</mi><mn>5</mn></msub></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><msub><mi>p</mi><mn>6</mn></msub></mtd></mtr></mtable><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></math>
, \[\]then 
<math><mrow><msup><mi>P</mi><mi>k</mi></msup><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>[</mo><mtable><mtr><mtd><msubsup><mi>p</mi><mn>1</mn><mi>k</mi></msubsup></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><msubsup><mi>p</mi><mn>2</mn><mi>k</mi></msubsup></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><msubsup><mi>p</mi><mn>3</mn><mi>k</mi></msubsup></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><msubsup><mi>p</mi><mn>4</mn><mi>k</mi></msubsup></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><msubsup><mi>p</mi><mn>5</mn><mi>k</mi></msubsup></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><msubsup><mi>p</mi><mn>6</mn><mi>k</mi></msubsup></mtd></mtr></mtable><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></math>
object.explanation:
<math><mrow><mrow><mi>tr</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mrow><mi>A</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>B</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>tr</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>tr</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>
\[\] 
<math><mrow><mrow><mi>tr</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>kA</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>·</mo><mrow><mi>tr</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>
\[\]Therefore,
<math><mrow><mi>tr</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo>·</mo><msup><mi>A</mi><mn>3</mn></msup></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>q</mi><mo>·</mo><msup><mi>A</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>r</mi><mo>·</mo><mi>A</mi></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>s</mi><mo>·</mo><mi>I</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>
)=
<math><mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo>·</mo><mrow><mi>tr</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>A</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>q</mi><mo>·</mo><mrow><mi>tr</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>A</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>r</mi><mo>·</mo><mrow><mi>tr</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>s</mi><mo>·</mo><mrow><mi>tr</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>I</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>
